direction.raw_text: And Archimedes, there's another one. He was into math, philosophy, all kinds of stuff, then one day he was working out an equation in the sand and somebody stabbed him. Crappy, I know.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A bus pulls up behind other parked and unloading buses.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: file off the buses, holding handmade "SAVE MARY" signs, stuffed animals, flowers, rosary beads, Kleenex. They head toward the fence to join the others.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Angus watches as Doug films Hartman interviewing Steve.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Steve, tell us about Mary, your fiance struggling for her life at the bottom of the abandoned mine as we speak. Steve glares at him. Hartman motions for him to go on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mary... she's smart, incredibly smart. She talks a lot. Never boring, I'll tell you that much. He thinks about her, gets lost in it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mary Horowitz doesn't pretend to be anything she's not. She's passionate, beautiful, real... and she definitely doesn't deserve to be where she is now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The spectators all gather, candles in hand, hands joined in silent prayer. An ELDERLY COUPLE hands Howard and Elizabeth candles. Howard looks around at the rest of the crowd - strangers watching, waiting, worried.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They don't even know her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, but they know what it's like to be alone, to need a helping hand. That's a good enough reason to be here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: hold a candlelight vigil on the lawn. The media catches every minute of it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bar PATRONS are silent, glued to the "Mary Watch" coverage on the overhead TV.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The old crane lowers the small rope into the hole, smoke seeping out of the motor. The Rescue Supervisor watches, anxious and helpless. The other Rescuers just watch. Nothing to do but wait.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mary still talks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Happenstance, I love that word too. And you know what else - Mary coughs. Before she has a chance to catch her breath, a rope with a small bag attached quickly drops next to her, the bag hitting the floor. Mary unties the bag and looks inside to find water and sandwiches.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No dessert. Crappy. Did you know that the word dessert comes from an old French word that means "clear the table"? Sometimes I feel like dinner is just doing time so I can get to the point, and of course the point always involves sugar. Who needs - The Little Deaf Girl covers her ears, vocalizes as much as she's able.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Shut up! I can't hear you but you talk a lot. Totally catches Mary off guard. She fully takes that in. Her demeanor completely shifts, a calm washes over her.,
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know. She sits down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know. She notices the Little Girl's shoes are soaked. Mary moves next to her, takes off her rubber boots and puts them on the Little Girl. Mary puts an arm around her, holds her close at - softly, her side, then speaks like she's a different person to herself, the Little Girl unable to read her lips.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not good at... silence. "Mary doesn't do quiet", that's how my grandmother always said it. "What's that hush?" she'd holler at a party. "It's Mary about to talk", then she'd laugh and laugh and laugh. Everybody would... But I knew something they didn't - that if you keep talking, if you keep on talking, you don't hear people telling you that you're different. You don't hear people saying they don't like you. And if you're talking, you just might not hear it when some kid... calls you a freak. Mary's eyes start to well.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I just wanted to be normal, that's all. Steve said I was. She thinks about it, laughs a bit.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm beginning to think newsmen can't entirely be trusted. She buttons up the Little Girl's sweater.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The truth is normal is -- not me. She seems surprised she said it out loud. There's relief in it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My friends, the people I've met over the past week, they're not normal either. They're more interesting, more original, more real, more rare. She suddenly gets it, brightens up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's where I fit. - and for She thinks about it, in silence. The sadness fades the first time, she's comfortably quiet. She smiles at the Little Deaf Girl. The Little Deaf Girl smiles back. And they sit -- Mary totally calm. Mary hears something in the distance - a gentle PLINK PLINK PLINK she couldn't have heard while talking. She picks up the flashlight, moves toward the noise. In a corner of the mine, a water drip hits on some old rusted mining tools, including two rusty vice grips. The Little Girl coughs. Mary looks back at her, concerned.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Little Deaf Girl, it's time for us to go home.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Howard, Elizabeth and Carlos watch from the fence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's taking so long?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. and Mrs. Horowitz are glued to the TV.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . HOROWITZ Why aren't they doing anything? Mr. Horowitz grabs her hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Laundry Sorters still glued to the Mary Watch coverage.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Quiet tension in the bar as the patrons all watch CNN.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A tense night in Eunice, Louisiana. Hartman what can you tell us?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Doug films Hartman. In the shot behind him, smoke seeps out of the old crane.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They've lowered food and water into the depths of this abandoned mine. The last task of this archaic crane that finally blew its motor. We've been told the new rescue equipment won't make it until daybreak. Until then, all we can do is wait, hope, and of course pray. There's a commotion at the rescue site. Doug zooms in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : The rope hanging into the hole is moving. Rescuers get as close to the hole as possible.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jesus Christ. Tell me she's not - 113.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mary cuts two pieces of excess rope off the bottom, attaches each it to the hanging rope using the vice grips as makeshift climbing ascenders.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: After I got kicked out of Girl Scouts, while the other girls were learning how to sell cookies, I was at home reading the biography of Sir Edmund Hillary. Mary motions for the Little Deaf Girl to jump on piggyback. She jumps up onto Mary's back, still in the red rubber boots. Mary starts jugging up the rope, the vice grips and rope pieces acting like ladder steps. They start rising up slowly. Not an easy task. Mary struggles every step.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A shot of the moving rope up above the hole is broadcast. People on the street stop and watch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Guys at the bar stand up to watch to the shot of the moving rope on TV.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. and Mrs. Horowitz on the edge of their seats in front of the Mary Watch TV coverage.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Little Deaf Girl helps Mary move one of the vice grips up the rope.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.0.) If life is like a crossword puzzle then its worth, its greatness, its raison d'efre should be judged in the same way.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Mary grasps the cable with everything she has, pulls up another step.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) Is it solvable? One of the red boots drops down into the mine shaft.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Every eye is on the moving rope.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mary looks up as the lights above get closer and closer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.0.) Is it entertaining?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As the Rescuers, Firemen, Troopers, Media and Public look on, Mary at last appears above ground, the little Girl in her arms.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) Does it sparkle? The crowd goes nuts. Cameras flash. Rescuers rush to help them onto the ground. An Ambulance Attendant grabs the little Girl, wraps her in a blanket. Mary's eyes flutter in the blinding lights of the cameras pointed at her. She scans the entire crowd.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.0.) And does it fit? Her eyes fix on a spot in the crowd. She starts running.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mrs. Horowitz hands her husband the box of Kleenex as they wail and watch Mary on TV, safely above ground.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The customers eat pie while they're glued to images of Mary and the little Girl.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good for her. Good for her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The staff breathe a sigh of relief when they see Mary alive on TV. Jim Soloman stares at the images, happy, acquiescent.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We're going to have to give her her job back. He shakes his head, laughs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Everybody in the bar celebrates. The BARTENDER rings the bell.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Career Day teacher watches Mary on TV, wipes her eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Laundry Sorters celebrate, then realize their laundry is all pink.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Large Kid from the Career Day class walks into the living room where his DAD has Mary Watch on TV. The Kid holds up a crossword, half done, and he's not happy about it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Did you start this and not bother finishing it? Do you know how much work goes into making these things? Honestly, Dad. The Kid grabs a pencil to finish the puzzle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Takihashi watches Mary on TV, wipes his tears.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mary adjusts her eyes to the flashing lights, looks around. An Ambulance Attendant tries to attend to her leg. She waves him off. In bare feet, blood running down her leg, limping, she starts running away from the site toward the media. Steve's watches, genuinely happy to see her. Hartman nudges Doug to get the camera on Steve.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: First interview is ours. Here comes our girl. Steve, you ready? Grab her arid kiss her then let me start with the questions. Doug focuses in on Steve. Hartman holds the crowd back so Mary can get to him. Mary runs toward them -- and keeps on running, right past Steve's open arms. She heads for her friends at the fence - Howard, Elizabeth, Carlos, George, Lydia, all of the other Protestors. She swan dives right into them. They catch her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're okay.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I am. Cameras go off all around them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Greyhound bus travels.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.0.) My brain is full of all kinds of information, some of it useful, some of it not. (MORE)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.0.) (cont'd) I've recently discovered, hiding in the back of my mind, somewhere between astrophysics and a catalog of candy bars of the Seventies, a previously hidden bit of knowledge more important than everything else. It is this...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mary sits right at the front talking to the female BUS DRIVER.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In solving the puzzle of life there's one thing you must do. She points to the side of the road. The bus pulls over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Find somebody just as normal as you. Mary stands up, gets off the bus.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: if not a whole bunch. Howard, Elizabeth, George, Lydia, Carlos, Clyde, a few old Ladies, a bunch of other Protestors file off the bus. Mary keeps talking to the bus driver.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And don't be a slave to your loins. Trust me on that one. Mary taps the side of her head.

direction.raw_text: You need to let this be the boss of you. Cornprende ?
